title: International Datathon on Animal Health Organised by the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH)
text: Welcome to the WOAH Datathon web page!

title: International Datathon on Animal Health Organised by the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH)
section: Overview
text:
Overview
The World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH) invites multidisciplinary teams to participate in an international datathon on animal health data science, focusing on surveillance, risk, trade and impact assessment.
Participants will work remotely over several months to address real‑world analytical challenges using pilot datasets provided by WOAH and partners. The datathon aims to stimulate innovation, methodological rigor and decision‑relevant analytics in animal health.
Winning teams will receive prize money, the opportunity to be featured in the Animal Echo and to present their work at a dedicated side event during the WOAH Global Session in 2027.

title: International Datathon on Animal Health Organised by the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH)
section: Who Can Participate
text:
Who Can Participate
The datathon is open to international, multidisciplinary teams (1–6 members), including but not limited to:

Data scientists and statisticians
Epidemiologists
Economists
Computer scientists
Public health and animal health professionals

Teams may include members from academia (students or faculty), public institutions, international organisations, NGOs or the private sector.

title: International Datathon on Animal Health Organised by the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH)
section: Datathon Format
text:
Datathon Format

Launch: Q2 2026
Duration: 3–4 months (remote participation)
Team work: Independent and asynchronous
Support: Documentation, data descriptions and periodic technical clarifications

Final submission: Analytical pipeline + results report on a git repo by September 30, 2026

title: International Datathon on Animal Health Organised by the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH)
section: Data & Outputs
text:
Data & Outputs
Each team will:

Select one challenge either from the list or self-proposed (subject to approval)
Develop a complete data science pipeline, including data processing, modelling and validation
Produce analytical outputs based on pilot or historical datasets
Document methods and results in a concise technical report
All code must be reproducible and submitted in a public or shared repository.

Contact: dataintegration.dept @ woah.org

title: International Datathon on Animal Health Organised by the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH)
section: Datathon Deliverable Assessment Criteria
text:
Datathon Deliverable Assessment Criteria

Scientific/Technical Accuracy
Definition: Measures correctness and rigor of the methods and outputs.
Key Points:
Appropriateness of modelling approach for the problem.
Correct handling of data (e.g., preprocessing, imputation, bias correction).
Logical and reproducible workflow from raw data to final output.
Validation against known or simulated benchmarks.
Scoring Tip: 0–5 scale; 5 = methodologically robust, fully validated, no obvious flaws.


Innovation and Creativity
Definition: Measures originality in problem-solving, methodology, or data integration.
Key Points:
Novel application of statistical, ML, or network techniques.
Creative integration of multiple data sources.
Unique visualization or decision-support approach.
Evidence of thinking beyond “textbook” solutions.
Scoring Tip: 0–5 scale; 5 = clearly innovative, methodologically or conceptually novel.


Practical Relevance / Policy Impact
Definition: Measures the degree to which outputs address WOAH priorities or real-world decision-making needs.
Key Points:
Alignment with animal health policy, surveillance, or trade risk objectives.
Interpretability for non-technical stakeholders.
Clarity of actionable insights or recommendations.
Responsiveness to intended problem scope.
Scoring Tip: 0–5 scale; 5 = deliverables are directly actionable and relevant.


Reproducibility and Documentation
Definition: Measures clarity and completeness of the workflow, code, and reporting.
Key Points:
Availability of scripts/notebooks and clear instructions.
Documentation of data sources, assumptions, and parameters.
Ability for independent evaluators to reproduce results.
Versioning or modular design supporting reuse.
Scoring Tip: 0–5 scale; 5 = fully reproducible and well-documented workflow.
Contact: dataintegration.dept @ woah.org

title: Datathon Deliverable Assessment Criteria
text: The material submitted submitted by each team will be assessed by a panel of experts based on the following criteria:

title: List of datathon challenges
text: Below is a list of challenges that are provided for guidance or source of inspiration. Once a topic is chosen by a team, the outline does not have to be followed strictly, excursions in some of the other topics and beyond are welcome.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 1 Early Outbreak Detection from Multi-Source Surveillance Data
text:
1 Early Outbreak Detection from Multi-Source Surveillance Data
Objective: Develop models for early detection of emerging animal health events.
Data:

WAHIS event notifications (historical)
Syndromic surveillance indicators
Trade/movement proxies
Environmental covariates

Methods:

Bayesian change-point detection
Spatio-temporal models
Anomaly detection

LSTM / transformer-based time series models

Deliverable:
End-to-end pipeline producing alerts with uncertainty quantification and interpretability.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 2 Spatio-Temporal Risk Mapping of Priority Transboundary Animal Diseases
text:
2 Spatio-Temporal Risk Mapping of Priority Transboundary Animal Diseases
Objective:

Produce dynamic risk maps for a selected priority disease (e.g. ASF, HPAI, FMD).
Data:


Historical outbreak locations

Livestock density

Climate data

Trade and movement indicators

Methods:


Hierarchical Bayesian models

Gaussian processes

Spatial ML (e.g. graph neural networks)

Deliverable:

Reproducible pipeline generating predictive risk surfaces and validation metrics.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 3 Nowcasting and Forecasting Disease Incidence Under Reporting Delays
text:
3 Nowcasting and Forecasting Disease Incidence Under Reporting Delays
Objective:

Correct for under-reporting and reporting delays in animal disease data.
Data:


Time-stamped notification data with known lags

Partial reporting histories

Methods:


Bayesian nowcasting

State-space models

Probabilistic forecasting

Deliverable:

Forecasts with credible intervals and comparison of methodological approaches.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 4 AI-Assisted Signal Extraction from Event-Based Surveillance Text
text:
4 AI-Assisted Signal Extraction from Event-Based Surveillance Text
Objective:

Extract and classify animal health signals from unstructured text sources.
Data:


News articles

Official reports

Social media or RSS feeds (curated sample)

Methods:


NLP pipelines

Transformer-based classification

Named entity recognition

Weak supervision

Deliverable:

Automated system producing structured signals linked to diseases, species, and locations.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 5 Cross-Country Comparability and Bias Assessment in Surveillance Data
text:
5 Cross-Country Comparability and Bias Assessment in Surveillance Data
Objective:

Quantify and adjust for heterogeneity in surveillance capacity and reporting practices.
Data:


WAHIS indicators

Country-level metadata (capacity indicators, reporting frequency)

Methods:


Latent variable models

Causal inference

Domain adaptation techniques

Deliverable:

Metrics and visualizations highlighting comparability issues and adjusted estimates.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 6 Antimicrobial Use and Resistance: Pattern Discovery and Prediction
text:
6 Antimicrobial Use and Resistance: Pattern Discovery and Prediction
Objective:

Explore relationships between antimicrobial use (AMU) and resistance (AMR) indicators.
Data:


Aggregated AMU and AMR datasets (animal sector)

Contextual production data

Methods:


Multivariate analysis

Causal graphs

Machine learning regression and clustering

Deliverable:

Analytical pipeline identifying patterns, risk factors, and predictive signals.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 7 One Health Integration: Linking Animal Health, Environment, and Climate Signals
text:
7 One Health Integration: Linking Animal Health, Environment, and Climate Signals
Objective:

Assess how environmental and climate variables modulate animal disease risk.
Data:


Disease occurrence data

Climate variables (temperature, rainfall)

Land-use proxies

Methods:


Joint models

Feature attribution methods

Interpretable ML

Deliverable:

Quantitative assessment of environmental drivers with policy-relevant interpretation.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 8 Automated Quality Assessment of Animal Health Data Submissions
text:
8 Automated Quality Assessment of Animal Health Data Submissions
Objective:

Detect inconsistencies, outliers, and implausible values in reported datasets.
Data:


Historical surveillance submissions with known data quality issues

Methods:


Rule-based checks combined with ML anomaly detection

Explainable AI

Deliverable:

Scalable data quality scoring framework and dashboard-ready outputs.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 9 Scenario Modelling for Disease Spread Under Control Strategies
text:
9 Scenario Modelling for Disease Spread Under Control Strategies
Objective:

Compare intervention strategies (movement restrictions, vaccination) using simulation.
Data:


Synthetic or pilot outbreak scenarios with parameter ranges

Methods:


Compartmental and agent-based models

Stochastic simulations

Deliverable:

Decision-support outputs comparing scenarios under uncertainty.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 10 Translation of Analytical Outputs into Decision-Ready Indicators
text:
10 Translation of Analytical Outputs into Decision-Ready Indicators
Objective:

Bridge advanced analytics and policy needs by designing interpretable indicators.
Data:


Outputs from one or more analytical pipelines above

Methods:


Indicator construction

Uncertainty communication

Visualization science

Deliverable:

A reproducible workflow producing indicators aligned with WOAH reporting needs.

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 11 Composite Observatory Indicators from Heterogeneous Data Streams
text:
11 Composite Observatory Indicators from Heterogeneous Data Streams
Challenge:

Design and validate composite indicators to monitor countries’ implementation of WOAH standards.
Data:


WAHIS quantitative indicators

Observatory qualitative assessments

Country metadata (income group, livestock sector structure)

Methods:


Latent variable models

Multi-criteria decision analysis

Uncertainty propagation

Deliverables:


Composite indicator methodology with uncertainty quantification

Sensitivity and robustness analyses

Documentation suitable for Observatory publication

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 12 Bias and Signal Separation in Observatory Monitoring Data
text:
12 Bias and Signal Separation in Observatory Monitoring Data
Challenge:

Distinguish true performance changes from reporting, compliance, or capacity effects.
Data:


Time series of Observatory-related indicators

Reporting histories

Methods:


Hierarchical Bayesian models

Measurement error models

Causal inference / sensitivity analysis

Deliverables:


Bias-adjusted time series

Diagnostic tools for signal vs reporting effects

Methodological guidance for interpretation

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 13 Linking Animal Health Performance to Economic Losses
text:
13 Linking Animal Health Performance to Economic Losses
Challenge:

Quantify economic losses associated with animal diseases using sparse or partial data.
Data:


Disease occurrence (WAHIS)

Livestock population and production proxies

GBADs pilot economic datasets

Methods:


Economic–epidemiological models

Imputation and data fusion

Scenario-based valuation

Deliverables:


Loss estimates with uncertainty bounds

Disease-specific economic impact profiles

Reusable valuation framework

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 14 Predictive Modelling of Animal Health Burden Under Alternative Investment Scenarios
text:
14 Predictive Modelling of Animal Health Burden Under Alternative Investment Scenarios
Challenge:

Estimate how changes in surveillance or control investment affect disease burden and losses.
Data:


Synthetic or pilot GBADs scenarios

Real surveillance data

Methods:


Counterfactual modelling

Decision analysis

Probabilistic simulations

Deliverables:


Investment–impact scenarios

Comparative burden trajectories

Policy-oriented summary outputs

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 15 Harmonising Epidemiological and Economic Metrics Across Countries
text:
15 Harmonising Epidemiological and Economic Metrics Across Countries
Challenge:

Build a framework linking epidemiological indicators (incidence, mortality) to economic burden metrics.
Data:


Multi-country pilot datasets

Methods:


Metric harmonisation

Scaling and standardisation

Cross-country comparability analysis

Deliverables:


Harmonised indicator framework

Cross-country comparison tools

Documentation for joint Observatory–GBADs use

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 16 Trade Disruptions Following Animal Health Events
text:
16 Trade Disruptions Following Animal Health Events
Problem:

Animal disease outbreaks often lead to asymmetric and poorly quantified trade impacts.
Objective:

Quantify how outbreaks affect bilateral and regional trade flows over time.
Data (pilot):


Disease outbreak timelines

Aggregated livestock/product trade data

Country and product metadata

Methods:


Interrupted time series

Difference-in-differences

Bayesian causal models

Deliverables:


Quantified trade impact estimates

Visual timelines of disruption and recovery

Methodological note on attribution

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 17 Predicting Trade Vulnerability to Animal Health Shocks
text:
17 Predicting Trade Vulnerability to Animal Health Shocks
Problem:

Some trade relationships are more fragile than others, but vulnerability is rarely quantified.
Objective:

Develop indicators of trade vulnerability to animal health events.
Data (pilot):


Trade networks

Historical outbreaks

Production and dependency proxies

Methods:


Network analysis

Risk scoring models

Graph-based ML

Deliverables:


Trade vulnerability indicators

Network-based risk visualisations

Ranking of high-risk trade relationships

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 18 Disease Risk Along Trade and Movement Networks
text:
18 Disease Risk Along Trade and Movement Networks
Problem:

Trade and movement routes can amplify disease spread, but are often treated crudely.
Objective:

Model disease risk propagation along trade-related networks.
Data (pilot):


Livestock/product trade matrices

Outbreak locations

Optional mobility proxies

Methods:


Network epidemiology

Spatio-network models

Simulation approaches

Deliverables:


Risk propagation metrics

Network-informed risk maps

Scenario-based simulations

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 19 Science-Based Regionalisation and Zoning Indicators
text:
19 Science-Based Regionalisation and Zoning Indicators
Problem:

Regionalisation decisions are critical but analytically under-supported.
Objective:

Design quantitative indicators supporting zoning/regionalisation under outbreaks.
Data (pilot):


Subnational outbreak data (or synthetic)

Trade exposure proxies

Control measures metadata

Methods:


Spatial risk aggregation

Scenario modelling

Uncertainty-aware indicators

Deliverables:


Zoning and regionalisation indicators

Scenario comparisons under uncertainty

Decision-support visual outputs

title: List of datathon challenges
section: 20 Consistency of Sanitary Measures with Observed Risk
text:
20 Consistency of Sanitary Measures with Observed Risk
Problem:

Trade restrictions may not always align with epidemiological risk.
Objective:

Compare observed trade measures with estimated disease risk.
Data (pilot):


Outbreak and risk estimates

Trade policy proxies (binary/ordinal)

Methods:


Risk–response analysis

Classification and clustering

Deliverables:


Risk–response consistency metrics

Typology of trade measures vs risk

Analytical framework for proportionality assessment

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Can a team consists of a single person?: yes
Can team members be from different countries?: yes
Can team members be from different organizations?: yes

text:
